div1.title: The Life of St Julian the Confessor
div1.l:
SEint Seint
Iulian þe confe&slong;&slong;our Confessour &punctelev; wa&slong; ibo&rrot;e at rome Rome ;
Muche folk þo&rrot;u&yogh; is p&rrot;echingue &punctelev; cri&slong;tine heo bicome.
Cri&slong;tinedom wa&slong; þo vnwurþe &punctelev; in þulke cite þere—
Gret &slong;co&rrot;n heo hadden of alle þulke &punctelev; þat icri&slong;tnede were,
And alle þat &slong;peken of cri&slong;tinedom Cristinedom &punctelev; heo defouleden heom inou&yogh;.
In Aunter aunter him dude þis holie man &punctelev; and þuderward &yogh;uyt him d&rrot;ou&yogh;,
Þat folk d&rrot;of to bu&slong;emare &punctelev; þe me&slong;te del echon.
Ake o&rrot;e louerd Ore Louerd &slong;ende him grace &punctelev; and fair miracle fo&rrot; him wrou&yogh;te,
And þat folk þo&rrot;u&yogh; is p&rrot;echingue &punctelev; to cri&slong;tinedom Cristinedom he b&rrot;ou&yogh;te.
Ore louerd Louerd him &yogh;af so fair grace &punctelev; þat with one wo&rrot;de he mi&yogh;te

Helen Meo&slong;ele&slong; meoseles and guidie Men men
&punctelev; and þe blinde &yogh;iuen heo&rrot;e &slong;i&yogh;t.
Þa&rrot;e na&slong; no manere vuel &punctelev; nou&yogh;wer þare he cam gon
Þo&rrot;u&yogh; þe vertue of þe croiz Croiz &punctelev; þat he ne helde heom anon,
So þat he to&rrot;nede to cri&slong;tinedom Cristinedom &punctelev; al þat folk þareaboute
And &slong;iweden him al&slong;o into Al al þat lond— &punctelev; of heom wel grete route—

So þat heo comen in one &slong;tude. &punctelev;
aþur&slong;t Aþurst heo weren wel &slong;o&rrot;e.
Heo nu&slong;ten &yogh;ware to d&rrot;inke come &punctelev; ; it greuede heom ful &slong;o&rrot;e.

Heo criden alle on &slong;eint Seint
Iulian &punctelev; þat he &slong;um d&rrot;inke heom founde.
Þi&slong; holie man nam op is &slong;taf &punctelev; , smot doun into þe grounde,
And pi&yogh;te þane poynt a luyte in þe eo&rrot;þe &punctelev; . þare Þare cam walle out anon,
Þet be&slong;te water þat mi&yogh;te beo &punctelev; , among heom euerechon.
And fond heom alle d&rrot;inke inou&yogh; &punctelev; , þare neuer er welle na&slong;,
Þo&rrot;u&yogh; vertue of þis holie man &punctelev; fair miracle þare was.

So mani fair Miracle miracle
o&rrot;e louerd Ore Louerd dude &punctelev; fo&rrot; loue of &slong;eint Seint
Iulian
Þat muche del of þat folk &punctelev; heolden him a god, a no man.
In gode&slong; Godes &slong;erui&slong;e ate la&slong;te &punctelev; his lijf he b&rrot;ou&yogh;te to ende,
And a luyte bifo&rrot;e candelma&slong;&slong;e Candelmasse &punctelev; to heouene he gan iwende.
Nou god God fo&rrot; is &slong;wete loue &punctelev; u&slong; þudere alle &slong;ende.

An oþur &slong;eint Seint
Iulian þare is &punctelev; þat men biddeth wel fa&slong;te.

After guod ·
In· in , in onecouth &slong;tude, &punctelev; &yogh;wane heo beoth &slong;o&rrot;e aga&slong;te.

div1.title: The Life of St Julian the Hospitaller
div1.note: The first two lines of Saint Julian the Hospitaller are written continuously with the life of St Julian the Confessor. Although they might be better taken as the introduction to the life of St Julian the Hospitaller the Latin rubric is written in line with the decorated initial "S" in "Seint", and this seems to suggest that the scribe perceived the second life as beginning with the words "Seint Iulian þare is þat men biddeth wel faste."

fw.hi:
Uita sc&combtilde;i Sancti Iuliani
boni ho&slong;pit&ssup; Hospitis ·

div1.l:
SEint Seint
Iulian þe guode herebeger Hereberger &punctelev; of noble kuynde com.
&slong;talewarde Stalewarde and &slong;trong man he was &punctelev; and louede wel cri&slong;tindom Cristindom .
A noblere bodi þane he wa&slong; &punctelev; nou&yogh;were na&slong; non ifounde.
A &slong;wyþe fair heo&rrot;t he i&slong;ai&yogh; &punctelev; and þareafter fa&slong;te he d&rrot;ou&yogh;.
He &slong;trencþede him to nime þat be&slong;t &punctelev; and &slong;iwede after fa&slong;te.
Þo þis heo&rrot;t hadde longe Io&rrot;ne iorne , &punctelev; he biturnde him ate la&slong;te
And &slong;pak with him a&slong;e god God it wolde &punctelev; . “Iulian,” he &slong;ede,
“&YOGH;wi &slong;iwe&slong;te me &slong;o fa&slong;te?” he &slong;eide. &punctelev; “ þou Þou &slong;chalt don an oþur dede.
Ake ne beo þou no þe wroþure with me &punctelev; , þei ich it þe telle.”
Þo þis guode man þis iheo&rrot;de &punctelev; , him bigan wond&rrot;i and d&rrot;ede
Fo&rrot; þat wilde be&slong;t &slong;o &slong;pack &punctelev; and fo&rrot; wo&rrot;de&slong; þat he &slong;ede.
Him wond&rrot;ede a&slong;e him mi&yogh;te wel &punctelev; , fo&rrot; it &slong;pak a&yogh;ein kuynde.
He wa&slong; aferd fo&rrot; ⁁þat he him bihet &punctelev; and ofte it hadde in muynde
Þat he &slong;cholde fader and moder sle &punctelev; . And to fleo þat dede
He wende out of contreie &slong;tilledliche, &punctelev; a&slong;e god God him wolde lede.
Into feo&rrot;rene contreie he wende &punctelev; so þat he cam bi cas
To a gret p&rrot;ince of a lond &punctelev; and in &slong;eruice wiz him wa&slong;.
Þat he made him mai&slong;ter of is ferd &punctelev; al fo&rrot;to gwie and lede.
And &slong;ethþe he made him we⁁di wijf, &punctelev; riche and noble al&slong;o,
A lauedi of a gret contreie &punctelev; and of grete mo&rrot;u&yogh;iue al&slong;o.
Bitwene him and is guode lauedie &punctelev; loue þare wa&slong; inov&yogh;,
Fo&rrot; to alle guodne&slong;&slong; bi heo&rrot;e mi&yogh;te &punctelev; eyþur to oþur d&rrot;ou&yogh;.

Ake is guode fader and is Moder moder
&punctelev; þat he bilefte him at om bihinde.
Swyþe &slong;orie weren fo&rrot; heo&rrot;e &slong;one &punctelev; þat heo ne mi&yogh;ten him nou&yogh;wer finde.
Heo wenden fo&rrot;th in a tyme, boþe, &punctelev; and &slong;ou&yogh;ten him wel wide
Fram o contreie to oþur fa&slong;te &punctelev; aboute in eche &slong;ide,
So þat heo iheo&rrot;den of him tellen &punctelev; , þei it were longue.
To is ca&slong;tel huy d&rrot;owen heom anon &punctelev; and faire weren onderfongue.
Heo ne founden nou&yogh;t him&slong;eof himseolf at hom &punctelev; ; ake is wijf heo wa&slong; þere.
Fair semblaunt heo made heom &punctelev; þo heo wu&slong;te &yogh;wat heo were.
Heo honourede heom þe mo&rrot;e &punctelev; for hire louerd ne wa&slong; nou&yogh;t þare,
And leide heom in heo&rrot;e owene bed &punctelev; and hire&slong;eolf lay elles&yogh;ware.
Amo&rrot;ewe are hit were dai &punctelev; heo aros op wel &slong;ofte
And to churche &yogh;eode wel &slong;tilleliche &punctelev; a&slong;e heo wa&slong; iwoned ofte.
Þo cam hire louerd hom &punctelev; In in þe mo&rrot;eweningue &slong;one
Þo iheo&rrot;de he wel &slong;ofte slepe &punctelev; and swei&yogh;en þarinne tweie,
A&slong;e Men men and wommen nede moten &punctelev; þat beoth werie of weie,

He &yogh;eode ner and i&slong;ai&yogh; þare ligge &punctelev;
Man man and womman also.
“&YOGH;e,” þou&yogh;te he, “ þis Þis is mi wijf, &punctelev; and &slong;um gering is icomen hire to.
I &slong;eo wel nouþe þat þe ho&rrot;e &punctelev; is iwonet here to.
Huy ne schullen neuereft ete mete &punctelev; ne mo&rrot;e schame me do.”
He slou&yogh; is fader and is moder &punctelev; mid is swerde þere
And wende bi heom þat is wijf &punctelev; and hire ho&rrot;eling it were.

And &yogh;eode him toward churche &punctelev; And and
tuynde tuyrnde þe do&rrot;e to.
A&slong;e he toward churche was &punctelev; his wijf hamward he mette.
“Louerd merci,” he þou&yogh;te, “ hou Hou is þis? &punctelev; ” with With gret wonder he ire grette:

“Dame,” he &slong;eide, “ hou Hou goth þis? &punctelev;
&yogh;wat &YOGH;wat do&slong;t þou nouþe here?

Ho liggez in o&rrot;e bedde at hom, &punctelev;
Man man and womman ifere?”
“A, sire Sire !” quath þis guode leuedi, &punctelev; “ wel Wel glad mi&yogh;t þou beo
Ihered beo o&rrot;e louerde&slong; Ore Louerdes grace &punctelev; þat þov mo&slong;t þis day i&slong;eo!
Þi fader and þi moder it is &punctelev; þat wide þe habbez i&slong;ou&yogh;t.
Ihered beo o&rrot;e louerde&slong; Ore Louerdes &slong;onde &punctelev; þat hidere heom hath ib&rrot;ou&yogh;t.
Leoue sire, hi&yogh;e þe hom &punctelev; — þou Þou &slong;chalt heom faire afonge—
And make with heom Ioie ioie inou&yogh; &punctelev; me þinchez er wel longe.”
“Nai! certe&slong; Certes ,” quath þis Iulian þo, &punctelev; “ &yogh;if &YOGH;if þat it is &slong;o,
Al mi bli&slong;&slong;e of þu&slong;&slong;e liue &punctelev; and mi Ioye ioye is al ido!
Alas þat ich Ich habbe þus longe ileoued, &punctelev; þat i ne hadde er ibeo ded!

Habbe ich Ich aslawe fader an Moder moder . &punctelev;
louerd Louerd &yogh;wat mai beo mi red?
Al to &slong;oth me &slong;eide þat wilde be&slong;t &punctelev; —alas þulke &slong;tounde!
Þei ich Ich habbe ifolewed his bihe&slong;te, &punctelev; þe soþe ich Ich habbe ifounde.
Er ich Ich habbe mine penaunce ido &punctelev; . god God leue me don mi be&slong;te.”

“A,
&slong;ire Sire , merci!” &slong;eide is wijf, &punctelev; “ &yogh;warefo&rrot;e &YOGH;warefore &slong;ei&slong;tþou so?
Sikerliche þou &slong;cha⁁lt at hom bileue &punctelev; and þine penaunce do.”
“Beo &slong;tille, dame,” Iulian &slong;eide, &punctelev; “ þou Þou &slong;pext al embe nou&yogh;t.
Certe&slong; I nelle neuere a&slong;tunte &punctelev; are ich Ich me habbe of londe ib&rrot;ou&yogh;t.
Ake haue guod dai, mi treowe &slong;pou&slong;e, &punctelev; and god God þe leue wel do.
“Alas!” &slong;eide þis guode wijf, &punctelev; “ &slong;ire Sire , &yogh;wi &YOGH;wi &slong;ei&slong;tþou so?
&YOGH;if god God wole þe &yogh;wyle we aliue beoth, &punctelev; ne &slong;chulle we departi atwo.
Bote þou wolle biþenche þe bet &punctelev; And and at hom bileue here.

Certe&slong;, &yogh;wodere þou euere iwen&slong;t, &punctelev;
ichulle Ichulle beo þi fere
And parti with þe of þi wo, &punctelev; a&slong;e ich Ich dude er of þi blis.
ÞIs Þis guode Man man and is trewe wijf &punctelev; wel &slong;tille fo&rrot;th heo iwende
And leten lond and leode, &punctelev; and al þat god God heom &slong;ende,
So þat heo wenden feo&rrot; and longue &punctelev; þat at þe la&slong;te heo come
To a deop watur and perilous, &punctelev; þare Men men ad&rrot;einten ilome.

Þis guode Men men a⁁d&rrot;einten⁁a&slong;tynte þer &punctelev; and leten heom &slong;one arereThe deletion and addition are in a later hand. It needs to be compared to other annotations throughout the MS.
A luytel hous—bote hit was guod—inou&yogh; &punctelev; bi&slong;ide þe watere þere.
Alle Men men þat þarefo&rrot;th come &punctelev; And and withoute hebo&rrot;ewe were,
He fond heom herebo&rrot;ewe guod inou&yogh; &punctelev; þat withoute none nere
Heo&rrot;e fet he wuch&slong; and baþede heom &punctelev; and duden al þat heo mi&yogh;te.
He bad alle þat to him come &punctelev; þat fo&rrot; heo&rrot;e &slong;oulene huy bede.
He po&rrot;ueide him of a schip &punctelev; and ouer þe watere ladde
Þarewith he swo⁁nk &slong;o&rrot;e inou&yogh; &punctelev; —of no man ne tok he nou&yogh;t.
&YOGH;wane he hadde ani mi&slong;ei&slong;e man &punctelev; ouer þe watere ibrou&yogh;t,
He ne let him nou&yogh;t fram him gon &punctelev; are huy amendede were.
He ladde heom into is hou&slong;e anon &punctelev; and ai&slong;ede heom &slong;wiþe wel þere.
Al heo duden fo&rrot;to bete þe &slong;unne &punctelev; of þat ca&slong; þat him bitidde
Fo&rrot; is fader &slong;oule, and is Moder moder , &punctelev; and bad fo&rrot; heom bidde.
Þarefo&rrot;e Men men &yogh;eot to þis day &punctelev; þat ouer lond doth iwende,

Heo biddeth to seint Seint
Iulian fa&slong;te &punctelev; þat he guod · In in · heom &slong;ende.

And seint Seint
Iulianes paterno&slong;ter &punctelev; ofte heo &slong;eggez al&slong;o
Fo&rrot; is fader &slong;oule, and is Moder moder , &punctelev; þat he b&rrot;ingue heom þarto.

Þo þis holie Man man
seint Seint
Iulian &punctelev; in þis trauail hadden hadde ibeo longe,

And mani Miseise miseise
Man man in is hou&slong; &punctelev; wel loueliche vnderfonge,
A day a&slong;e he hadde ibeo &punctelev; in trauaile &slong;trong inou&yogh;,
A&slong;e ladde þis men ouer &punctelev; and into is Inne inne heom d&rrot;ou&yogh;.
And a&yogh;ein middel ny&yogh;t to is bed &punctelev; &yogh;eode at þen ende
Fo&rrot;to habbe &slong;um re&slong;te þere &punctelev; &yogh;if o&rrot;e louerd Ore Louerd it wolde heoim &slong;ende.
Atþe midny&yogh;t a&slong;e he bigan &punctelev; &slong;umdel re&slong;te afongue,
A&yogh;eondhalf þe watere þare cam on &punctelev; in grete fo&rrot;&slong;te and &slong;trongue.
“Aris, Iulian, anon,” he gradde, &punctelev; “ hiderward Hidwerward þou mo&slong;t go
And b&rrot;ingue me ouer þis watere &slong;one, &punctelev; oþur ich Ich dei&yogh;e fo&rrot; wo.”
Þis guode man heo&rrot;de &slong;one þis &punctelev; and, þei he weri were,
He wende to þis &slong;eli man &punctelev; and ladde him ouer þere.
Mid chele and mid oþur wo &punctelev; , is lime&slong; him weren binome.
A lodlich mu&slong;el he þou&yogh;te al&slong;o, &punctelev; and þe foule&slong;te þat mi&yogh;te beo.

A
Miseisio&rrot;e miseisiore man þane he þou&yogh;te &punctelev; no man ne mi&yogh;te i&slong;eo.
Seint Iuliane ladde þis &slong;eli man &punctelev; Into into is hou&slong;e bi ni&yogh;te
And fondede to maken him an Ay&slong;e ayse &punctelev; bi al is trewe mi&yogh;te.
Gret fuyr he dude him makien and guod, &punctelev; þat he were of chele ib&rrot;ou&yogh;t,
And leide þarebi wel &slong;ofte, &punctelev; ake al it wa&slong; fo&rrot; nou&yogh;t.
His owene bed he let faire &slong;p&rrot;eden &punctelev; and b&rrot;ou&yogh;te him þareInne þareinne .

Cloþe&slong; inowe opon him he &slong;p&rrot;adde &punctelev; and holede helede him wel fa&slong;teA small mark below the "o" in "holede" may indicate that the scribe attempted to correct it to an "e".
&YOGH;eot he þou&yogh;te ful &slong;o&rrot;e ofcale &punctelev; for al þat he on him ca&slong;te,
Swyþe so&rrot;i wa&slong; was þis guode man &punctelev; and &slong;ore him aga&slong;te.
Þo he him dude al þat he mi&yogh;te, &punctelev; and þe chele &slong;o longe ila&slong;te,

He &slong;tod and biheold þis &slong;elie man, &punctelev; a
Musel musel a&slong;e he wende.
Sone &slong;o o&rrot;e louerd Ore Louerd it wolde, &punctelev; is hev&yogh; bigan amende.
At þe la&slong;te he werth &slong;o fair a man &punctelev; a&slong;e euere any mi&yogh;te beo,
And &slong;o cler he bicam &slong;one &punctelev; þat vnneþes men mi&yogh;ten him &slong;eo.
“Iulian,” he &slong;eide, “ god God it þe &yogh;elde &punctelev; þat þou me ha&slong;t ido.
In o&rrot;e louerde&slong; Ore Louerdes erinde of heuene &punctelev; icome ich Ich am þe to.
Ore louerd Louerd þe &slong;ente wo&rrot;d bi me &punctelev; þat þou art clanliche i&slong;ch&rrot;iue
And þine penaunce ha&slong;t wel ido, &punctelev; and þine &slong;unne&slong; beoth fo&rrot;&yogh;iue.
·b And boþe &yogh;e &slong;chullen with alle Ioye ioye &punctelev; newene come him to.”
Þo he hadde þis wo&rrot;d i&slong;eid, &punctelev; he nu&slong;te &yogh;ware he bicam.

Þis guode man seint Seint
Iulian &punctelev; to gode&slong; Godes &slong;erui&slong;e him nam,
Sone afterward in his &slong;erui&slong;e &punctelev; heo deiden boþe to
And wenden to þe bli&slong;&slong;e of heuene, &punctelev; þare heo &slong;chullen euere beo.

Guod it is to herebo&rrot;ewi Mi&slong;ei&slong;e miseise
me&combmacr; men
&punctelev; bi heom þat men mowen i&slong;eo.
Fo&rrot; þarewith þis holie man &punctelev; his &slong;unne&slong; bette inou&yogh;,
And a gret haluwe in heouene he is, &punctelev; þei he fader and moder a&slong;lou&yogh;.

Bidde we &yogh;eo&rrot;ne sein Sein
Iulian &punctelev; þat he o&rrot;e erinde beode
Þat o&rrot;e louerd Ore Louerd us &yogh;iue milce and o&rrot;e, &punctelev; and alle þat habbez neode.
Þat, &yogh;wanne we oþur any c&combtildevert;&slong;tine Cristine man &punctelev; ouer lond &slong;chullen wende,
Fo&rrot; is fader &slong;oule, and is moder, &punctelev; þat he guod herebo&rrot;ewe us &slong;ende.
Into þe bli&slong;&slong;e of heuene &punctelev; and þare withouten ende beo.
